At that time, the king named Abhiya was traveling in the country and passed by the Buddha on the road. He was covered in dust and dirt. He untied his sword and lowered his parasol to pay homage to the Buddha.
The Heavenly Honored One said:
Take a seat.
The king then sat down.
The Buddha asked the king:
Where have you come from, covered in dust and dirt?
The king then stepped back, bowed his head, and replied:
Yes!
Recently, while traveling in the country, there have been disasters and strange occurrences.
The Buddha told the king:
The king should govern with proper Dharma, without losing proper measure, and always nourish the people with a compassionate mind, so as to attain hegemony and governance.
The reason kings rule countries is all due to the good deeds they have done in past lives. In managing affairs for the people, they should not be biased or unjust.

The officials, the masses, and even the common people all have complaints. If the king's governance is not fair, the entire country will be resentful. After death, their souls will always enter the hells of Mount Tai. Later, even if they regret it, there is nothing they can do about it.

If the king governs the country fairly and appropriately, the ministers and people will praise his virtue and the four seas will turn to him. The gods, dragons, and spirits will all hear of the king's goodness. After death, he will ascend to heaven and have no regrets later.

The king should not indulge in lust to ruin himself. He should not harm others out of anger. He should accept the admonitions of loyal ministers and be straightforward. When speaking to others, he should always be lenient and not rash.
The king should treat the people with four intentions.
What are the four?
Providing timely assistance, speaking with a harmonious mind, sharing his precious treasures with the people, and caring for the elderly, sick, and widowed.
If the king is like this, the country will be peaceful and he will obtain its blessings. Upon death, he will ascend to heaven and his wishes will naturally be fulfilled.

The king cannot always be self-indulgent, respected and feared by all, and consider that as joy. Famous elephants, fine horses, jeweled carriages, wise ministers, officials, and hundreds of officers leading in front and following behind, precious treasures in the inner treasury, and hundreds of items in the granaries will all rot and decay, with nothing remaining.

Young people will eventually grow old, the strong will inevitably become ill, and all living beings will eventually die. Precious treasures, wives, children, and the inner and outer quarters cannot always be obtained. It is like a person dreaming of a palace, beautiful gardens, trees, flowers, fruits, ponds, and flowing springs, playing and enjoying themselves to the utmost, but upon waking, they suddenly disappear and cannot be found. All that exists in the world is like a person's dream.
Have you seen trees with flowers and fruits? The flowers and fruits cannot always remain on the tree, and even the lush leaves will eventually wither and fall.
Heavenly crowns, headdresses, embroidered robes, and famous garments cannot always remain beautiful, and flowing water cannot always remain full.
Setting a fire in the wilderness, the raging flames will soon die out;

Violent winds, heavy rain, thunder and lightning will suddenly disappear in an instant, and when the sun is about to rise, the stars lose their luster. The sun's abundant light illuminates the world, but it will soon be dark. The impermanence of the world is also like this.

It is like a great rocky mountain on all four sides, with six mountains above and below, all coming together at the same time. The people and creatures within, regardless of rank, will all be crushed to pieces.
There are four things that cannot be stopped by people:

When old age arrives, the body withers; when illness comes, the mind is troubled; when the body dies, the spirit departs; all precious treasures must be abandoned and cannot be kept. When one of these four arrives, there is no escape or avoidance. It cannot be guarded by words or pleaded with to be excused. It cannot be obtained by offering wealth or begging for mercy.
At that time, all the famous elephants, fine horses, precious treasures, strong men, ministers, and officials guarding and leading in front and back, who could push it away for the king?

Has the king ever seen a lion, the most ferocious of beasts, who, seeing a herd of deer from afar, intends to take them, and then rushes forward to tear them apart and eat their flesh? How can such pain be spoken of?

Life is like a lion taking a herd of deer. When a person's life is about to end, the body is not at ease, the blood vessels are drying up, the complexion changes, and life is about to be cut short. The five internal organs are not treated, and one does not think of food and drink. Even with powerful spells, good doctors, and fine medicine, one cannot be cured.

The mouth speaks falsely, and the family indulges whatever it demands. The whole body is in pain, as if being whipped. The hands and feet struggle, and the joints are about to disintegrate. The mouth is dry, the breath is exhausted, and the body is emaciated and weak. One cannot sit or lie down without help.

If one obtains good medicine, porridge, or sweet food, one should take it. One will certainly suffer greatly, with muscles and veins about to snap, only exhaling without inhaling again, lips parched and dry, true qi exhausted, and evil qi remaining everywhere;

The tongue slightly retracts, the facial features are colorless, the ears and nose are blocked and do not hear sounds or smells, the hands and feet are cramped and the muscles are tight, the mouth is clenched and one cannot speak, the hands may grasp at empty space on the side, white sweat and tears flow out continuously, the mind and thoughts are in pain, consciousness gradually dissipates and disappears, and one no longer knows anything. The warmth leaves the body, it becomes cold, and the soul departs.

All precious treasures, parents, brothers, wife and children, inner and outer acquaintances, and servants will all be abandoned, and one goes alone with one's actions, not knowing where one will end up. Although the world is pleasant, one cannot stay long.
At that time, O King, on whom should one rely?

There is only filial piety, kindness, and nurturing the two parents, serving the pure and virtuous renunciants, seeing ordinary elders and respecting them, sharing wealth and treasures with the people, being kind-hearted and bestowing kindness upon the people, not using slander to harm the lives of the people. The king's law should proclaim the sacred way, teaching the people to do good, only guarding the one mind, the mind dwelling on the Three Treasures.
If the king is like this, the sages praise him, and the devas, nÄgas, and spirits protect his country. In life he has glory and honor, and in death he ascends to the heavens.
When the body dies and the spirit departs, what can one rely on?
Only rely on goodness.

When the fire is blazing, rely on water to extinguish it. When a person is hungry and thirsty, rely on water and grains. When old, rely on a cane. When blind, rely on those with eyes. When in darkness, rely on lamplight. When sick and gravely ill, rely on good doctors and medicine. When a ship travels on the great ocean with strong winds and waves, rely on the rudder and oars. When the body dies and the spirit departs, one can only rely on cultivating goodness. Even if one encounters difficulties, one can rely on one's own affairs to save oneself and bring peace to the clan.

The king cannot be happy. The most delicious food and drink, leisurely living, and freedom cannot be obtained forever. When one is full, it will all be digested and scattered, and one cannot obtain it forever. Smelling good incense on the body, the fragrant breeze blowing in the nose, pearl necklaces shining in the eyes, beautiful flowers from water and land used as decorations, golden brocade woven into famous clothes:
white felt clothes, embroidered clothes, colorful clothes, boundless clothes, fine cotton clothes, fine clothes, brocade and silk clothes, all of these are impermanent and cannot last forever.

Palaces, high terraces, magnificent halls and residences, golden, silver, and seven-jeweled beds, woolen and cotton blankets and cushions, soft and fine to touch for the body, made of woven seven treasures with embroidered brocade curtains, pillars, beams, hall doors carved and engraved, burning various incense powders to play and enjoy within, all of this is impermanent and cannot last.

Lutes, zithers, flutes and pipes, a collection of various sounds, singing and dancing, performances and entertainment, the multitude of sounds filling the ears with joy, this too is impermanent, like an illusion, like a dream, and cannot last.

Elephant, horse, jeweled carriages, the sight of which is captivating, when the king goes out once, he beats the bell and sounds the drum, with messengers leading the way in front and behind. The king rides in a carriage with feathered canopy, and attendants hold banners, with peacock feathers and variegated plumage carved on the handles to brush off dust and dirt. The roads are repaired and filled, with vermilion-painted railings. The multitude who see it all respect and fear it. Fine flowers and famous incense are all used to welcome the king, proclaiming 'May the king live ten thousand years,' but this too is difficult to ensure.
Have you ever seen a person about to die, Your Majesty?

All the people inside and outside the house gather around them, beating their chests and crying out in distress, sobbing and choking with tears streaming down, lamenting, 'Alas, the spirit alone departs:
'Why do you abandon us like this?'
Those who hear it are heartbroken, and those who see it cannot help but grieve.

Carrying them out of the city and abandoning them in the wilderness, flying birds and running beasts peck and gnaw at them. Worms in the body eat the flesh. Sun-scorched and wind-blown, the bones become dry. The former kings, honored and wealthy, were also like this, Your Majesty. Today, they suddenly disappear and are never seen again.
This is a clear proof of impermanence.

How much more so for today? King, contemplate this well, do not think of lust, do not listen to flattery, testify to people entering into crimes, should accept loyal admonitions and govern with moderation, should fear the severe punishments of hell, all blood-sucking insects are greedy for life and should not kill them.
